awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Advanced Infrastructural Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Society of Civil Engineers 2017 Infrastructure Report Card gave a poor grade of D+ on the current condition of the US infrastructure. Deteriorating infrastructure is greatly impeding the nation's ability to compete in the thriving global economy, and significant upgrading is necessary to ensure our country remains globally competitive. Upgrading the nation's infrastructure requires advancement in infrastructure materials and technologies and well-trained engineers with expertise in advanced infrastructure materials. To fulfill this need, the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette will provide undergraduate students with hands-on research and training opportunities in advanced infrastructure materials to encourage students to pursue careers and graduate degrees in this field. The REU site aims at supporting workforce development of materials engineers and promoting diversity in the engineering community.

Ten undergraduate researchers, mainly comprised of underrepresented minority and female students, will be hosted at the REU Site every summer for three years. Each year, the undergraduate researchers will participate in a 10-week hands-on interdisciplinary research program and work under the supervision of faculty advisors on a variety of research projects related to advanced infrastructure materials. The research projects range from fundamental materials research to innovative structural systems composed of advanced materials. An educational field trip, workshops and seminars (on Grand Challenges of US Infrastructure, Research Methods and Research Ethics, Technical Writing and Presentation Skills, Graduate School Life and Application Process, and Careers in STEM) will be organized to: 1) train students in research and technical communication skills; 2) cultivate their interest in pursuing advanced degrees and career in engineering field; 3) give them a direct insight into the challenges our infrastructure is facing; and 4) offer them a unique experience of southern Louisiana infrastructure problems, culture and landscape. A diverse group of highly educated researchers and engineers with expertise in advanced infrastructural materials will be created through this REU Site, contributing towards enhancement of the US infrastructure and a more diverse engineering community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to establish a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at University of Louisiana - Lafayette (UL Lafayette) to host a total of 30 undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds to conduct hands-on research on a variety of research projects in advanced infrastructure materials. The REU site encouraged the participating students to pursue a career and/or advanced degrees in the field of infrastructure materials, and promote diversity in the engineering community.  During the award period, we successfully ran four summer REU programs instead of three due to the disruption caused by COVID.  In each of the summers the REU program was held, the undergraduate researchers (UGRs) participated in a 10-week hands-on interdisciplinary research program.   The UGRs worked under the supervision of experienced faculty advisors within the College of Engineering at UL Lafayette on an array of research projects related to advanced infrastructure materials.

 

Eight professional development seminars/workshops were offered to the UGRs on the following topics: Grand Challenges of US Infrastructure; Research Methods and Research Ethics; Effective Literature Search; Technical Writing and Presentation Skills; Graduate School Life and Application Process; Graduate Studies in Engineering; Resume Building; and Careers in STEM. These seminars provided training opportunities for the participants that included polishing their research and communication skills, and providing them career advice.

 

Aside from the scholarly goals, the UGRs undertook two field trips that included: (1) Louisiana Transportation Research Center (LTRC); and (2) Cleco Alternative Energy Center. The students were able to see how advanced infrastructure materials were tested at LTRC and how the Cleco Center investigated ways to provide clean and affordable energy.

 

In early December of the year preceding each of the summer REU program years, the PI reached out to all faculty members within College of Engineering at UL Lafayette with research interests in advanced infrastructural materials and encouraged them to participate in the REU program as faculty mentors. At the end of January of the summer program year, the participation of six to eight faculty mentors was confirmed. The PI also engaged faculty mentors from underrepresented groups to attract student applicants from similar backgrounds. Each year, among the faculty mentors, one was African American.  The PI utilized the nsfetap.org website to publicize the Advanced Infrastructure Materials (AIM)-REU site and receive applications. The application portal was open for three months in each of the program years. Each year, the PI reached out to the department heads at several civil engineering programs requesting them to bring this REU opportunity to the attention of their undergraduate students. In particular, we reached out to minority serving universities and liberal art colleges. The applicants were asked to  preference rank of the available 12-16 research projects. Summaries of research projects were provided on the AIM-REU website.

 

At the end of March of each program year, we received a fairly large number of applications --93 student applications was the highest number in 2021.  Based on the student qualifications, research interest and their academic, cultural, and economic background, we selected the desired number of students from very diverse backgrounds.  Among the thirty students that participated in the program, twelve (40%) were female and eight (27%) were from underrepresented minority groups. We made sure the students represented a diverse group of universities ranging from minority serving institutions to primarily undergraduate serving institutions.

 

Prior to the arrival of the students, logistics of the entire program were carefully planned. Brochures were provided to UGRs ahead of time with useful information of the campus, housing, dining, etc. Before the start of the 10-week program, the PI met individually with all the faculty mentors and explained to them the expectations of the REU site and shared detailed plans of all activities.

 

During the 10-week program the students conducted research under the supervision of the mentors on a wide spectrum of projects. Working with the faculty mentors, the participating students conducted hands-on experimental or field research and obtained extensive training in research method, experimental skills, data analysis, and technical communications.

 

The students made two presentations about their research. The first one was a study plan oral presentation during the 3rd week of the program, and the second one was a final poster presentation at the research symposium held at the very end of the program.

 

Assessment of all the activities and overall REU program was conducted with the help of an external evaluator who worked on design and analysis of the evaluations. Feedback on all the seminars, workshops, and field trips were collected by requesting the UGRs to fill out a survey immediately after the activity. The results of the external evaluation was very encouraging since the participating UGRs were extremely satisfied with their participation in the REU program and several of the participants presented the results of their research in national technical meetings/conferences.
